thread.title: Shelter quickly fills with Oroville dam evacuees
thread.title_full: Shelter quickly fills with Oroville dam evacuees

title: Shelter quickly fills with Oroville dam evacuees
text: Shelter quickly fills with Oroville dam evacuees 0:37 Tempers flare in Marysville traffic 0:55 Evacuees wait to fill gas tanks at Quik Stop on Hwy 99 and Bogue Road 0:49 Evacuees jam Marysville gas stations 0:07 Streams of cars seen fleeing Oroville area 1:08 Lake Oroville eyes new storms expected to arrive Thursday 0:58 Watch: Drone flies over auxiliary spillway at Lake Oroville 0:34 Point Pleasant resident evacuates flooded home 1:22 Sacramento area flooding through the years: 1862-2017 0:46 See water rush at Oroville Dam as untested emergency spillway activated 1:43 Water continues to rush down Oroville spillway on Friday 0:35 See dramatic aerial views of damaged Oroville Dam spillway More Videos Water continues to rush down Oroville spillway on Friday The Department of Water Resources said it planned to slow releases from Oroville Dam’s damaged main spillway “to prevent erosion along the north side of the spillway from compromising nearby power line towers.” The lines run to the dam’s power plant. See dramatic aerial views of damaged Oroville Dam spillway This aerial view of Oroville Dam shows how surging, muddy water is spilling from the fractured main spillway. Assemblyman Brian Dahle, R-Bieber, posted the video on his Facebook page with this note: "(Butte County) Sheriff (Kory) Honea took my Chief of Staff up to view the dam." Brianna Reynolds saw her rent rise by 47 percent Brianna Reynolds lost her Oak Park home after her rent rose by 47 percent. A housing crisis is driving more people into poverty than ever before, a phenomenon state housing experts and advocates attribute to a shortage of homes and skyrocketing demand.
